Ingredients: Marinade: 1/2 cup yogurt, 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste, 1/2 tsp red chili powder, Salt
Steps: Marinate chicken with marinade ingredients for at least 30 minutes.
Grill or pan-fry the chicken until cooked. Set aside.
Heat butter in a pan. Add chopped onion and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add tomato puree, red chili powder, and salt. Cook until the oil separates.
Blend the sauce until smooth (optional, for restaurant-style).
Return sauce to pan, add cooked chicken, garam masala, and kasuri methi.
Simmer for 5-7 minutes.
Stir in the heavy cream. Cook for 2 more minutes and serve hot.
Marinate and cook chicken tikka as in the Butter Chicken recipe.
Heat oil in a separate pan. Sauté onions and bell peppers until soft.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add tomato puree, turmeric, coriander, cumin, and salt. Cook until gravy thickens.
Add the cooked chicken tikka pieces to the gravy.
Stir in garam masala and heavy cream.
Simmer for 5-10 minutes and serve.
Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add chopped onion and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Add tomato puree, turmeric, coriander powder, chili powder, and chana masala powder.
Cook the masala until oil separates.
Add the boiled chickpeas and 1 cup of water (or the water chickpeas were boiled in).
Add salt, mix well, and bring to a simmer.
Cover and cook for 10-15 minutes on low heat.
Garnish with fresh cilantro.

Ingredients: 1 large bunch spinach (palak), blanched and pureed
Steps: Blanch spinach in hot water for 2-3 minutes, then transfer to cold water. Drain and blend to a smooth puree.
Heat oil/ghee in a pan. Add cumin seeds.
Add chopped onion and sauté until translucent.
Add ginger-garlic paste and chopped tomato. Cook until tomatoes are soft.
Add turmeric, red chili powder, and salt. Cook for 1-2 minutes.
Add the spinach puree and cook for 5-7 minutes.
Add the paneer cubes and garam masala. Stir gently.
Simmer for 5 minutes. Stir in cream (if using) just before serving.
Soak lentils and kidney beans overnight. Pressure cook with salt until very soft (about 6-8 whistles).
Do not drain the water. Lightly mash some of the lentils.
In a separate pan, heat butter. Sauté onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Add tomato puree, red chili powder, and garam masala. Cook until oil separates.
Pour this tempering into the cooked lentils.
Add salt, mix well, and let it simmer on low heat for at least 30 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Stir in the heavy cream just before serving.
Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds.
Add sliced onion and sauté until translucent.
Add grated ginger and chopped tomato. Cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add turmeric, coriander powder, and chili powder. Stir for 30 seconds.
Add the potato cubes and cauliflower florets. Add salt and mix well to coat with spices.
Cover and cook on low-medium heat for 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until vegetables are tender.
Garnish with cilantro and serve.

Ingredients: 1/4 cup cashews, soaked in warm water
Steps: Make a paste of the soaked cashews.
Heat butter in a pan. Sauté onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add tomato puree, chili powder, turmeric, and salt. Cook until oil separates.
Add the cashew paste and cook for another 3-4 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add 1 cup of water and bring to a simmer. Let the gravy cook for 5 minutes.
Add the paneer cubes, garam masala, and kasuri methi.
Simmer for 5 minutes. Stir in the heavy cream and serve hot.

Ingredients: Dough: 1 cup all-purpose flour, 2 tbsp ghee, 1/4 tsp ajwain (carom seeds), Salt, Water

Filling: 2 large potatoes (boiled, peeled, and mashed), 1/2 cup green peas (boiled), 1 tsp grated ginger, 1 green chili (chopped), 1/2 tsp cumin seeds, 1 tsp coriander powder, 1/2 tsp garam masala, Salt, Oil for deep frying
Steps: For dough: Mix flour, salt, ajwain, and ghee. Rub until it resembles breadcrumbs. Add water slowly to form a stiff dough. Cover and rest for 30 minutes.
For filling: Heat 1 tbsp oil. Add cumin seeds, ginger, and green chili. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add coriander powder, garam masala, and boiled peas. Cook for 1 minute.
Add mashed potatoes and salt. Mix well and cook for 2-3 minutes. Let it cool.
Make small balls from the dough. Roll into an oval shape. Cut in half.
Take one half, form a cone, and stuff it with the potato filling. Seal the edges using water.
Heat oil in a pan on medium-low heat. Deep fry the samosas until golden brown and crisp.

Ingredients: Nigella seeds (kalonji) and cilantro for topping
Steps: Dissolve sugar and yeast in warm milk. Let it sit for 10 minutes until frothy.
In a large bowl, mix flour and salt. Make a well in the center.
Pour in the yeast-milk mixture, yogurt, and 1 tbsp of melted butter.
Knead into a soft, smooth dough. Cover and let it rise in a warm place for 1-2 hours.
Knead the dough again. Divide into equal-sized balls.
Roll each ball into a teardrop shape. Sprinkle with nigella seeds and cilantro, pressing them in.
Heat a cast-iron skillet (tava) over high heat.
Place the naan on the hot tava. When bubbles appear, flip it.
Cook the other side directly over the flame (using tongs) until charred spots appear.
Brush with the remaining melted butter and serve hot.

Ingredients: 1 whole chicken, skin removed and cut into 4 pieces
Marinade 1: 1 tbsp lime juice, 1 tsp red chili powder, Salt
Marinade 2: 1 cup thick yogurt, 2 tbsp ginger-garlic paste, 1 tsp garam masala, 1 tsp coriander powder, 1 tsp cumin powder, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1 tbsp kasuri methi, 2 tbsp vegetable oil
Steps: Make deep gashes in the chicken pieces.
Apply the first marinade (lime juice, chili powder, salt) and let it rest for 15 minutes.
In a bowl, mix all ingredients for the second marinade.
Coat the chicken pieces thoroughly with the second marinade. Refrigerate for at least 4 hours, or overnight.
Preheat oven to 220°C (425°F).
Place chicken on a baking rack over a tray.
Bake for 20-25 minutes, then flip and bake for another 10-15 minutes, or until cooked through and charred.
Baste with oil or butter halfway through. Serve with onion rings and lemon wedges.

Ingredients: 2 cups Basmati rice, soaked for 30 minutes
Whole spices: 1 bay leaf, 2-inch cinnamon, 4 green cardamoms, 4 cloves
A pinch of saffron soaked in 2 tbsp warm milk
Steps: Marinate chicken with yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, chili powder, turmeric, biryani masala, and salt for 1 hour.
Cook the soaked Basmati rice with whole spices and salt until 70% done. Drain and set aside.
In a heavy-bottomed pot, heat ghee. Add the sliced onions and sauté until golden.
Add the marinated chicken and cook for 10-15 minutes until partially cooked.
Layer the cooked rice over the chicken.
Sprinkle fried onions, mint, cilantro, and the saffron-milk over the rice.
Cover the pot tightly (dum). Cook on low heat for 20-25 minutes.
Gently fluff the rice and serve hot with raita.

Ingredients: 2 cups Basmati rice, soaked for 30 minutes
2 cups mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, beans, potatoes), cubed
Whole spices: 1 bay leaf, 2-inch cinnamon, 4 green cardamoms, 4 cloves
A pinch of saffron soaked in 2 tbsp warm milk
Steps: Marinate vegetables with yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, chili powder, biryani masala, and salt for 30 minutes.
Cook the soaked Basmati rice with whole spices and salt until 70% done. Drain and set aside.
In a heavy-bottomed pot, heat ghee. Add sliced onions and sauté until golden.
Add the marinated vegetables and cook for 10 minutes until partially cooked.
Layer the cooked rice over the vegetables.
Sprinkle fried onions, mint, cilantro, and the saffron-milk over the rice.
Cover the pot tightly (dum). Cook on low heat for 20 minutes.
Gently fluff the rice and serve hot with raita.

Ingredients: 1 cup kidney beans (rajma), soaked overnight and boiled
Steps: Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds.
Add chopped onion and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Add tomato puree, turmeric, coriander powder, chili powder, and rajma masala powder.
Cook the masala until oil separates.
Add the boiled rajma along with its cooking water.
Add salt, mix well, and bring to a simmer.
Cover and cook on low heat for 20-30 minutes, mashing a few beans to thicken the gravy.
Serve hot with rice (chawal).

Ingredients: Koftas: 1 cup mashed potatoes, 1/2 cup grated paneer, 2 tbsp cornflour, Salt, Chopped nuts (cashews, raisins)
Gravy: 1 onion (boiled paste), 1/2 cup tomato puree, 1/4 cup cashew paste, 1/4 cup heavy cream, 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste, 1/2 tsp garam masala, 1/2 tsp red chili powder, 2 tbsp oil, Salt
Steps: For koftas: Mix mashed potatoes, paneer, cornflour, and salt. Make small balls, stuffing a few nuts in the center.
Deep fry the koftas until golden brown. Keep aside.
For gravy: Heat oil. Add ginger-garlic paste.
Add the boiled onion paste and sauté for 2-3 minutes.
Add tomato puree, chili powder, and salt. Cook until oil separates.
Add the cashew paste and cook for 2 more minutes, stirring constantly.
Add 1 cup of water and garam masala. Simmer for 5 minutes.
Stir in the heavy cream.
Just before serving, gently place the koftas in the hot gravy. Do not boil after adding koftas.
Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds.
Add chopped onion and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add tomato puree, turmeric, coriander powder, and chili powder. Cook until oil separates.
Add the boiled green peas and 1 cup of water. Bring to a simmer.
Add the paneer cubes and salt.
Cover and cook for 5-7 minutes.
Stir in the garam masala and serve hot.

Ingredients: 500g mutton or lamb, cut into pieces
1 tbsp Kashmiri red chili powder (for color)
Whole spices: 2 bay leaves, 2 black cardamoms, 4 green cardamoms, 1-inch cinnamon, 4 cloves
Steps: Heat mustard oil in a pressure cooker until it smokes. Let it cool slightly.
Add asafoetida and all the whole spices. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add sliced onions and fry until golden brown.
Add the mutton pieces and fry on high heat until browned on all sides.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1-2 minutes.
Lower the heat. Add the whisked yogurt, stirring continuously to prevent curdling.
Add Kashmiri chili powder, fennel powder, dry ginger powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add 1 cup of water. Secure the lid and pressure cook for 5-6 whistles or until the mutton is tender.
Let the pressure release naturally. Simmer for a few more minutes if the gravy is too thin.

Ingredients: Dosa Batter: 1 cup parboiled rice, 1/2 cup raw rice, 1/4 cup urad dal (black lentils), 1 tsp fenugreek seeds, Salt

Potato Masala: 3 large potatoes (boiled and mashed), 1 onion (sliced), 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 tsp chana dal, 1 tsp urad dal, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 2 green chilies (chopped), 1-inch ginger (grated), Curry leaves, 2 tbsp oil, Salt
Steps: For batter: Soak rices and lentils/fenugreek separately for 6 hours. Grind to a smooth paste. Mix, add salt, and ferment overnight.
For masala: Heat oil. Add mustard seeds, chana dal, and urad dal. Sauté until golden.
Add onion, green chilies, ginger, and curry leaves. Sauté until onions are soft.
Add turmeric, mashed potatoes, and salt. Mix well. Cook for 2-3 minutes.
For dosa: Heat a flat non-stick pan (tava). Pour a ladle of batter in the center and spread outwards in a circular motion to make a thin crepe.
Drizzle 1/2 tsp of oil or ghee around the edges.
When the dosa turns golden and crisp, place 2-3 tbsp of the potato masala in the center.
Fold the dosa and serve hot with sambar and chutney.
Wash and soak the urad dal (with fenugreek) and idli rice in separate bowls for at least 4-6 hours.
Drain the urad dal and grind it in a wet grinder or blender, adding water sparingly, until you get a very smooth, fluffy batter.
Drain the rice and grind it to a slightly coarse texture.
Combine the ground dal and rice batter in a large bowl. Add salt and mix well with your hands.
Cover the bowl and let the batter ferment in a warm place for 8-12 hours, or until it has risen and doubled in volume.
Grease the idli plates with oil. Stir the fermented batter gently.
Pour the batter into the idli molds.
Steam in an idli cooker or a large pot with boiling water for 10-12 minutes.
Let it rest for 5 minutes before demolding. Serve hot with sambar and chutney.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup mixed vegetables (drumstick, carrots, brinjal, pumpkin)
1 tbsp tamarind pulp, soaked in 1/2 cup warm water
Tempering: 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1/2 tsp asafoetida (hing), 2 dried red chilies, 1 sprig curry leaves, 1 tbsp oil
Steps: Pressure cook the toor dal with turmeric and 2 cups of water until soft and mushy. Whisk it well.
In a separate pot, cook the mixed vegetables, onion, and tomato with 1 cup of water until tender.
Add the cooked dal to the vegetables.
Add the tamarind water, sambar powder, and salt. Mix well.
Let the sambar simmer for 10-15 minutes on low heat.
For tempering: Heat oil in a small pan. Add mustard seeds. When they pop, add red chilies, curry leaves, and asafoetida.
Pour the tempering over the simmering sambar. Mix and serve hot.

Ingredients: Tempering: 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 tsp urad dal, 1 dried red chili, 1 sprig curry leaves, 1 tsp oil
Steps: In a blender, combine grated coconut, roasted chana dal, green chilies, ginger, and salt.
Add a little water at a time and grind to a smooth paste.
Transfer the chutney to a bowl.
For tempering: Heat oil in a small pan. Add mustard seeds. When they pop, add urad dal, red chili, and curry leaves.
Sauté until the urad dal turns golden.
Pour the tempering over the chutney and mix.
Serve with idli, dosa, or vada.

Ingredients: Vada: 2 large potatoes (boiled, mashed), 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 tsp ginger-garlic-chili paste, 1/2 tsp turmeric, Curry leaves, Salt
Batter: 1 cup gram flour (besan), 1/4 tsp turmeric, Pinch of baking soda, Salt, Water
Steps: For vada: Heat 1 tbsp oil. Add mustard seeds, curry leaves, and ginger-garlic-chili paste. Sauté.
Add turmeric, mashed potatoes, and salt. Mix well. Let it cool and form into round patties.
For batter: Mix besan, turmeric, baking soda, and salt. Add water to make a thick, smooth batter.
Dip the potato patties (vada) into the batter and deep fry in hot oil until golden brown.
To assemble: Slit the pav bun, leaving one side intact.
Generously spread green chutney on one side and dry garlic chutney on the other.
Place the hot vada in the center. Serve immediately.
In a large bowl, combine all the vegetables (onion, potato, spinach).
Add gram flour, rice flour, ajwain, chili powder, turmeric, and salt.
Sprinkle a small amount of water (1-2 tbsp at a time) and mix. The moisture from the vegetables should be enough to bind the flour. You want a very thick, coating batter, not a liquid one.
Heat oil in a pan for deep frying.
Drop spoonfuls of the vegetable-batter mixture into the hot oil.
Fry on medium heat, turning occasionally, until golden brown and crisp.
Drain on a paper towel and serve hot with chutney or ketchup.

Ingredients: Batter: 1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 tbsp gram flour (besan), 1/2 tsp active dry yeast, 1 tsp sugar, 3/4 cup warm water
Syrup: 1 cup sugar, 1/2 cup water, 4-5 strands of saffron, 1/2 tsp cardamom powder, 1 tsp lemon juice
Ghee or oil for deep frying
Steps: For syrup: Boil sugar, water, and saffron until it reaches a one-string consistency. Add cardamom powder and lemon juice (to prevent crystallization). Keep it warm.
For batter: Mix flour, besan, sugar, and yeast in a bowl. Add warm water to make a smooth, thick, pancake-like batter.
Cover and let it ferment in a warm place for 1-2 hours.
Heat ghee/oil in a flat-bottomed pan on medium heat.
Fill the fermented batter into a squeeze bottle or a piping bag.
Squeeze the batter in a circular, overlapping motion directly into the hot oil to form the jalebi spirals.
Fry until golden and crisp on both sides.
Remove the jalebi from the oil, drain, and immediately soak in the warm sugar syrup for 1-2 minutes.
Remove from syrup and serve hot.

Ingredients: Jamuns: 1 cup milk powder, 1/4 cup all-purpose flour, 1/4 tsp baking soda, 1 tbsp ghee, 2-3 tbsp milk (to knead)
Syrup: 1.5 cups sugar, 1.5 cups water, 2-3 green cardamoms (crushed), A few strands of saffron
Ghee or oil for deep frying
Steps: For syrup: Boil sugar, water, cardamom, and saffron. Simmer for 5 minutes until the syrup is slightly sticky. Turn off heat.
For jamuns: In a bowl, mix milk powder, flour, and baking soda.
Rub in the ghee with your fingertips.
Add milk, 1 tbsp at a time, to form a soft, smooth dough. Do not knead too much.
Grease your palms and make small, smooth, crack-free balls from the dough.
Heat ghee/oil on low heat. The oil should be just hot enough, not smoking.
Add the balls to the oil. They will sink and then rise. Fry on low heat, stirring gently, until they are dark golden brown (this can take 10-15 minutes).
Drain the fried jamuns and add them directly to the warm (not hot) sugar syrup.
Let them soak for at least 1-2 hours before serving.

Ingredients: 1/4 cup Basmati rice, soaked for 30 minutes
Steps: Drain the soaked rice. Coarsely grind it or leave it whole.
In a heavy-bottomed pot, bring the milk to a boil.
Add the rice to the boiling milk. Reduce the heat to low.
Simmer, stirring frequently to prevent sticking, for 25-30 minutes, or until the rice is cooked and the milk has thickened.
Add the sugar, cardamom powder, and saffron.
Stir and cook for another 5-10 minutes, until the sugar is dissolved.
Stir in the nuts and raisins.
Serve warm or chilled.
In a blender, combine the chilled yogurt, water/milk, sugar, and cardamom powder.
Blend for 1-2 minutes until smooth and frothy.
If it's too thick, add a little more water or milk.
Pour into glasses. Add ice cubes if desired.
Garnish with a pinch of cardamom powder or chopped pistachios.
Serve immediately.

Ingredients: 1 cup ripe mango pulp (fresh or canned)
2-3 tbsp sugar (or to taste, depending on mango sweetness)
Steps: In a blender, combine the mango pulp, chilled yogurt, milk/water, sugar, and cardamom powder.
Blend until smooth and creamy.
Taste and adjust sugar if needed.
If the lassi is too thick, add a splash of milk or water and blend again.
Pour into tall glasses and serve chilled.
Garnish with a small slice of mango or mint leaf.
Squeeze the excess water from the grated cucumber.
In a bowl, combine the whisked yogurt, grated cucumber, roasted cumin powder, black salt, and regular salt.
Mix well.
Garnish with chopped cilantro.
Chill in the refrigerator for 30 minutes before serving.
Serve as a side dish with biryani, pulao, or parathas.
Roast the eggplant directly over a flame (or in the oven) until the skin is charred and the flesh is soft.
Let it cool. Peel off the charred skin and mash the pulp.
Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds.
Add chopped onion and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies. Sauté for a minute.
Add chopped tomatoes, turmeric, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until tomatoes are mushy and oil separates.
Add the mashed eggplant pulp. Mix well and cook for 5-7 minutes, stirring often.
Sprinkle with garam masala and garnish with cilantro.
Serve hot with roti.
Heat 1 tbsp of oil in a pan. Add the cut okra and sauté on medium-high heat until it's 80% cooked and no longer slimy. Remove from the pan and set aside.
In the same pan, heat the remaining 1 tbsp of oil. Add cumin seeds.
Add sliced onion and sauté until translucent.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Add chopped tomato, turmeric, coriander powder, chili powder, and salt.
Cook until the tomatoes are soft.
Add the sautéed okra back to the pan.
Stir in the amchur powder. Mix well and cook for another 3-5 minutes.
Serve hot with roti or paratha.

Ingredients: Tadka (Tempering): 2 tbsp ghee, 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1/2 tsp asafoetida (hing), 1 onion (finely chopped), 1 tomato (finely chopped), 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste, 1/2 tsp red chili powder, 2 dried red chilies
Steps: Rinse the dal. Pressure cook the dal with 3 cups of water, turmeric, and salt for 3-4 whistles until soft.
For tadka: Heat ghee in a small pan.
Add cumin seeds and asafoetida. When they splutter, add the dried red chilies.
Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and chopped tomato. Cook until tomatoes are soft.
Add the red chili powder, stir for 10 seconds, and turn off the heat.
Pour this tadka over the cooked dal.
Mix well and simmer for 2 minutes. Garnish with cilantro and serve hot.
Rinse the poha in a colander until it softens. Do not soak. Let it drain.
Add salt, sugar, and turmeric to the damp poha and mix gently.
Heat oil in a pan. Fry the peanuts until crisp. Remove and keep aside.
In the same oil, add mustard seeds. When they pop, add curry leaves and green chilies.
Add chopped onion and potato. Sauté until potatoes are tender.
Add the poha mixture to the pan. Stir gently to combine everything.
Cover and cook on low heat for 2-3 minutes.
Turn off the heat. Add lemon juice, fried peanuts, and chopped cilantro. Mix well.
Garnish with sev and serve hot.
Dry roast the semolina in a pan on low heat until it turns aromatic. Remove and keep aside.
Heat oil/ghee in the same pan. Add mustard seeds, urad dal, and chana dal. Sauté until dals are golden.
Add ginger, green chilies, and curry leaves. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add chopped onion and sauté until translucent.
Add the mixed vegetables and cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add the hot water, salt, and turmeric (if using). Bring to a rolling boil.
Slowly add the roasted semolina, stirring continuously with your other hand to prevent lumps.
Keep stirring until the semolina absorbs all the water and thickens.
Cover and cook on low heat for 3-5 minutes.
Turn off the heat. Add lemon juice and 1 tsp of ghee (optional). Fluff with a fork and serve hot.
In a bowl, mix the chopped onion, tomato, green chilies, and cilantro. Add a pinch of salt.
Heat a flat non-stick pan (tava) over medium heat. Grease lightly with oil.
Pour a large ladle of the batter onto the pan. Do not spread it thin; it should be thick like a pancake.
Sprinkle a generous amount of the onion-tomato topping mixture over the uttapam.
Gently press the toppings into the batter with a spatula.
Drizzle 1 tsp of oil around the edges and a little on top.
Cover and cook for 2-3 minutes on low-medium heat, until the bottom is golden.
Flip the uttapam carefully. Cook the other side (topping side) for 1-2 minutes.
Flip again, cook for 30 seconds, and serve hot with sambar and chutney.

Ingredients: 1 cup urad dal (black lentils), whole, skinned
Steps: Wash and soak the urad dal for at least 3-4 hours.
Drain the water completely. Grind the dal in a blender or wet grinder, adding water 1 tsp at a time, to make a thick, fluffy, and smooth batter.
Transfer the batter to a bowl. Add green chilies, ginger, curry leaves, onion, coconut (if using), crushed pepper, and salt.
Beat the batter with your hand for 2-3 minutes to aerate it.
Heat oil in a pan for deep frying.
Wet your palms. Take a small portion of the batter on your palm, flatten it, and make a hole in the center with your thumb.
Gently slide the vada into the hot oil.
Fry on medium heat, turning occasionally, until golden brown and crisp on the outside and cooked on the inside.
Drain on a paper towel and serve hot with sambar and coconut chutney.

Ingredients: Bhaji: 2 large potatoes, 1 cup cauliflower, 1/2 cup green peas, 1/2 cup carrots (all boiled and mashed)
1 large onion (finely chopped), 1 capsicum (finely chopped), 2 large tomatoes (pureed)
Steps: Heat 2 tbsp of butter in a large pan. Add chopped onion and sauté until translucent.
Add chopped capsicum and ginger-garlic paste. Sauté for 2 minutes.
Add tomato puree, chili powder, turmeric, and pav bhaji masala. Cook until oil separates.
Add the boiled and mashed vegetables. Mix well.
Add 1 cup of water and salt. Use a potato masher to mash the mixture directly in the pan.
Simmer for 10-15 minutes, mashing occasionally, until the bhaji is thick and well-combined.
Add 1 tbsp of butter and chopped cilantro. Mix well.
To serve: Slit the pav buns. Heat 1 tbsp of butter on a tava, add a pinch of pav bhaji masala, and toast the buns until lightly browned.
Serve the hot bhaji with the toasted pav, chopped onions, and a lemon wedge.

Ingredients: Bhature: 2 cups all-purpose flour, 1/2 cup semolina (sooji), 1/2 cup yogurt, 1/2 tsp baking soda, 1 tsp sugar, Salt to taste, Water to knead, Oil for deep frying
Steps: Prepare the Chole (Chana Masala) as per the recipe provided earlier.
For bhature: In a bowl, mix flour, semolina, yogurt, baking soda, sugar, and salt.
Add water slowly to knead a soft, pliable dough. Apply 1 tsp of oil and knead again.
Cover the dough and let it rest in a warm place for at least 2 hours.
Knead the dough again. Divide into equal-sized balls.
Roll each ball into an oval or round shape.
Heat oil in a pan on high heat.
Carefully slide the rolled bhatura into the hot oil. Press it down gently with a spatula to help it puff up.
Fry until golden brown on both sides.
Drain on a paper towel and serve immediately with the hot chole.

Ingredients: 1/4 cup mixed nuts (cashews, almonds, pistachios), chopped
Steps: In a large, heavy-bottomed pan, combine the grated carrots and milk. Bring to a boil.
Cook on medium heat, stirring frequently, until all the milk has evaporated (this can take 45-60 minutes).
Add the ghee to the pan. Sauté the carrot mixture for 10-15 minutes, until the color darkens and the ghee starts to separate.
Add the sugar and mix well. The sugar will melt and the mixture will become moist again.
Continue to cook, stirring, until the moisture from the sugar evaporates.
Add the cardamom powder, chopped nuts, and crumbled khoya (if using).
Stir well and cook for another 5 minutes.
Serve hot.

Ingredients: 2 tbsp lemon juice (mixed with 2 tbsp water)
1 tsp cornflour or all-purpose flour (optional, for binding)
Steps: Bring the milk to a rolling boil. Turn off the heat.
Add the lemon juice mixture slowly, stirring gently, until the milk curdles and separates from the greenish whey.
Strain the curdled milk through a muslin cloth. Rinse the 'chena' (curdled milk solids) under cold water to remove the lemon taste.
Squeeze the muslin cloth to drain all the whey. Hang it for 30 minutes.
Transfer the chena to a plate. Knead it with the heel of your palm for 8-10 minutes until it becomes smooth and releases some fat. Mix in cornflour if using.
Make small, smooth, crack-free balls from the chena.
In a large, wide pressure cooker or pot, combine sugar and 4 cups of water. Bring to a boil, stirring to dissolve the sugar.
Carefully add the chena balls to the boiling syrup.
If using a pressure cooker, close the lid and cook for 1 whistle, then reduce heat and simmer for 5-7 minutes. If using an open pot, cover and boil for 15-20 minutes.
Turn off the heat. Let the pressure release naturally. The rasgullas will have doubled in size.
Add rose water. Chill the rasgullas in the syrup for 4-6 hours before serving.

Ingredients: Batter: 1 cup gram flour (besan), 1/2 cup semolina (sooji), 1/2 cup yogurt, 1/2 inch ginger (grated), 1 green chili (paste), 1/2 tsp turmeric, Salt, 1 tsp Eno fruit salt (or baking soda)
Tempering: 2 tbsp oil, 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 sprig curry leaves, 2-3 green chilies (slit), 1 tbsp sugar, 2 tbsp water, 1 tbsp lemon juice
Steps: In a bowl, mix besan, sooji, yogurt, ginger-chili paste, turmeric, and salt. Add water to make a thick, idli-like batter. Let it rest for 20 minutes.
Grease a steaming pan. Boil water in a steamer.
Just before steaming, add the Eno fruit salt to the batter and stir quickly until it's light and frothy. Pour immediately into the greased pan.
Steam for 15-20 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted comes out clean.
Let it cool for 10 minutes, then cut into squares.
For tempering: Heat oil. Add mustard seeds, curry leaves, and green chilies.
Add water, sugar, and lemon juice. Bring to a boil and turn off the heat.
Pour this tempering evenly over the dhokla squares. Garnish with cilantro and grated coconut.
Dry roast the coriander seeds, cumin seeds, and dried red chilies. Coarsely grind them to make the kadai masala.
Heat 1 tbsp oil in a pan (kadai). Sauté the cubed onion and capsicum on high heat for 2-3 minutes until lightly charred. Remove and set aside.
In the same pan, heat 1 tbsp oil. Add the finely chopped onion and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add the tomato puree, turmeric, and salt. Cook until oil separates.
Add the freshly ground kadai masala and garam masala. Cook for 1-2 minutes.
Add the paneer cubes, sautéed onion, and capsicum. Stir gently to coat.
Add 1/4 cup of water, cover, and simmer for 5 minutes.
Garnish with cilantro and serve hot.

Ingredients: 2 large potatoes, peeled and quartered (optional, but traditional)
Vindaloo Paste: 6-8 dried Kashmiri red chilies (less spicy), 4-5 cloves garlic, 1-inch ginger, 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1/2 tsp black peppercorns, 1/2-inch cinnamon, 3 cloves
Steps: Grind all ingredients for the 'Vindaloo Paste' with the vinegar to a smooth paste.
Marinate the chicken pieces in this paste for at least 1 hour.
Heat oil in a pan. Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown.
Add the tomato puree and turmeric. Cook for 3-4 minutes.
Add the marinated chicken and the quartered potatoes.
Sauté on high heat for 5-7 minutes, until the chicken is seared.
Add 1 cup of water, salt, and sugar. Bring to a boil.
Cover, reduce heat, and simmer for 20-25 minutes, or until the chicken and potatoes are cooked through.
The gravy should be thick. Serve hot.

Ingredients: 2 cups mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, beans, potatoes)
Gravy Paste: 1/4 cup cashews, 1/4 cup grated coconut, 1 tsp poppy seeds (optional), 1/2-inch cinnamon, 2 green cardamoms, 2 cloves
Steps: Grind all ingredients for the 'Gravy Paste' with a little water to a very smooth paste.
Boil or steam the mixed vegetables until just tender. Keep aside.
Heat oil in a pan. Add the chopped onion and sauté until translucent.
Add ginger-garlic paste and chopped tomato. Cook until tomatoes are soft.
Lower the heat. Add turmeric and chili powder.
Add the ground gravy paste and sauté for 3-4 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add the whisked yogurt, stirring quickly to prevent curdling. Cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add the boiled vegetables, 1 cup of water, and salt. Bring to a simmer.
Cover and cook for 5-7 minutes.
Stir in the garam masala and serve hot.

Ingredients: Dough: 2 cups whole wheat flour (atta), Water, Salt, 1 tbsp oil

Filling: 3 large potatoes (boiled, peeled, and mashed), 1 onion (finely chopped), 1-2 green chilies (finely chopped), 1/4 cup chopped cilantro, 1/2 tsp amchur (dry mango powder), 1/2 tsp garam masala, Salt to taste
Steps: For dough: Knead a soft, smooth dough from the flour, salt, oil, and water. Cover and rest for 20 minutes.
For filling: In a bowl, combine mashed potatoes, onion, green chilies, cilantro, amchur, garam masala, and salt. Mix well.
Make equal-sized balls from the dough and the filling.
Take one dough ball, flatten it, and place a filling ball in the center.
Bring the edges of the dough together to seal the filling inside. Form a smooth ball.
Dust with dry flour and gently roll it out into a 6-7 inch circle (paratha).
Heat a tava (griddle) over medium heat.
Place the paratha on the tava. Cook for 30 seconds, then flip.
Drizzle 1/2 tsp of ghee/oil on the cooked side. Flip again.
Drizzle ghee/oil on the other side. Press gently with a spatula and cook until both sides have golden brown spots.
Serve hot with yogurt, pickle, or butter.

Ingredients: 1 tsp ghee or oil (optional, for dough)
Steps: In a large bowl, combine the flour and salt. Add the 1 tsp of ghee/oil (if using).
Slowly add the warm water, a little at a time, and knead to form a soft, pliable dough. Knead for 5-7 minutes.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 20-30 minutes.
Knead the dough again for 1 minute. Divide into small, equal-sized balls.
Take one ball, dust it with dry flour, and roll it into a thin, even circle (about 6-7 inches).
Heat a tava (griddle) over medium-high heat.
Place the roti on the hot tava. Cook for about 15-20 seconds, until small bubbles appear.
Flip the roti. Cook the other side for about 30 seconds.
Using tongs, lift the roti and place it directly on the open flame. It should puff up immediately.
Flip and cook the other side on the flame for a few seconds.
Remove from heat and brush with ghee.
Serve hot.
In a bowl, mix the flour, salt, and ajwain.
Add the 1 tbsp of oil and mix.
Add water, a little at a time, to knead a stiff, firm dough (stiffer than roti dough).
Cover and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.
Knead the dough again. Divide into small, equal-sized balls.
Grease your rolling pin and rolling surface with a little oil (do not use dry flour).
Roll each ball into a small, even circle (about 4-5 inches).
Heat the oil for deep frying in a pan (kadai) over high heat.
To check if the oil is hot, drop a tiny piece of dough; it should rise to the surface immediately.
Gently slide a rolled-out puri into the hot oil. It will sink and then rise.
Gently press the center of the puri with a slotted spoon to help it puff up.
Once puffed, flip it and fry the other side until golden brown.
Remove and drain on a paper towel. Serve hot with curry or bhaji.

Ingredients: 500g boneless chicken, cut into small cubes
Batter: 1/4 cup cornflour, 2 tbsp rice flour, 1 tbsp ginger-garlic paste, 1 tsp red chili powder, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1 egg (beaten), Salt
Tempering: 2 tbsp oil, 1 tsp mustard seeds, 10-12 curry leaves, 4-5 green chilies (slit), 1 tbsp ginger-garlic (chopped), 2 tbsp yogurt (whisked), 1 tsp red chili sauce (optional)
Steps: In a bowl, combine the chicken cubes with all the ingredients for the batter. Mix well to coat the chicken. Let it marinate for 30 minutes.
Deep fry the marinated chicken pieces in hot oil until golden brown and crisp. Drain and set aside.
For tempering: Heat 2 tbsp of oil in a separate pan.
Add mustard seeds. When they pop, add chopped ginger-garlic, green chilies, and curry leaves. Sauté for one minute.
Lower the heat. Add the whisked yogurt and red chili sauce. Stir quickly to prevent curdling.
Add the fried chicken pieces to the pan. Toss well to coat the chicken with the tempering.
Sauté on high heat for 1-2 minutes until dry. Serve hot as an appetizer.

Ingredients: 500g firm white fish (like pomfret or kingfish), cut into steaks

Masala Paste: 1 cup grated coconut, 1 tsp coriander seeds, 1/2 tsp cumin seeds, 1/2 tsp turmeric powder, 4-5 dried Kashmiri red chilies, 1 small onion, 1-inch ginger, 4-5 cloves garlic, 1 small ball of tamarind
Steps: Grind all the 'Masala Paste' ingredients with a little water to a very smooth, fine paste.
Rub the fish steaks with a little salt and turmeric. Set aside.
Heat coconut oil in a pan. Add the finely chopped onion and sauté until translucent.
Add the chopped tomato and cook until soft.
Add the ground masala paste and sauté for 5-7 minutes, until the raw smell disappears and oil starts to separate.
Add 1.5 cups of water and salt. Bring the curry to a boil.
Gently slide the fish steaks into the simmering curry.
Cook on medium-low heat for 8-10 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through. Do not stir too much, or the fish will break.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

Ingredients: Tempering: 2 tbsp oil, 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 tsp chana dal, 1 tsp urad dal, 2 tbsp peanuts, 2-3 green chilies (slit), 1 sprig curry leaves, 1/4 tsp asafoetida (hing)
Steps: In a bowl, mix the cooked rice with turmeric, salt, and 1 tbsp of oil. Separate the grains. Set aside.
Heat oil in a pan for tempering.
Add mustard seeds. When they pop, add chana dal, urad dal, and peanuts.
Sauté until the dals and peanuts are golden brown.
Add the green chilies, curry leaves, and asafoetida. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Turn off the heat. Pour this tempering over the rice.
Add the lemon juice.
Mix everything gently with a fork or your hands, ensuring you don't break the rice grains.
Garnish with cilantro and serve.

Ingredients: Tempering: 3 tbsp sesame oil, 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 tsp chana dal, 1 tsp urad dal, 2 tbsp peanuts, 3-4 dried red chilies, 1 sprig curry leaves, 1/4 tsp asafoetida (hing)
Steps: In a small pan, heat the tamarind pulp with turmeric and salt. Cook for 3-4 minutes until the raw smell is gone. Let it cool.
Heat sesame oil in a separate pan for tempering.
Add mustard seeds. When they pop, add chana dal, urad dal, peanuts, and dried red chilies.
Sauté until the dals and peanuts are golden.
Add curry leaves and asafoetida. Sauté for 30 seconds and turn off the heat.
In a large bowl, combine the cooled rice, the tamarind paste, and the tempering.
Mix well, preferably with your hands, to ensure the rice is evenly coated.
Let it rest for at least 30 minutes for the flavors to meld. Serve at room temperature.

Ingredients: 2 cups long-grain Basmati rice, soaked 30 mins
2 large onions, thinly sliced and deep-fried (Birista)
Whole spices: 1 bay leaf, 1 star anise, 2-inch cinnamon, 4 green cardamoms, 4 cloves
Pinch of saffron soaked in 2 tbsp warm milk
Steps: Marinate chicken with yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, chili powder, turmeric, biryani masala, half the fried onions, mint, cilantro, lemon juice, 2 tbsp ghee, and salt. Set aside for 2 hours.
Par-cook the soaked Basmati rice with whole spices and salt until 70% done. Drain thoroughly.
In a heavy-bottomed pot (handi), spread the marinated chicken in a single layer.
Layer the 70% cooked rice evenly over the raw chicken.
Sprinkle the remaining fried onions, mint, cilantro, saffron milk, and remaining 2 tbsp of ghee on top of the rice.
Cover the pot with a tight-fitting lid. Seal the edges with dough (dum) or use a heavy weight on top.
Cook on high heat for the first 5-7 minutes. Then, reduce the heat to the lowest possible setting and cook for 30-35 minutes.
Let it rest for 10 minutes before opening. Gently fluff and serve hot with raita.

Ingredients: Whole spices: 2 bay leaves, 4 green cardamoms, 1-inch cinnamon, 4 cloves
Steps: Crush the fried onions. Set aside.
Heat ghee/oil in a pan. Add the whole spices and sauté for 30 seconds.
Add the chicken pieces and fry on high heat until lightly browned.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for 2 minutes.
Lower the heat. Add the whisked yogurt, stirring continuously.
Add chili powder, turmeric, coriander powder, and salt. Cook the masala for 5-7 minutes.
Add the cashew/almond paste and the crushed fried onions. Sauté for 3-4 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add 1.5 cups of water. Bring to a boil, then cover and simmer for 15-20 minutes, or until the chicken is tender.
Stir in the garam masala and kewra essence. Serve hot.
Make a smooth paste of the boiled onion and soaked cashews.
Heat butter/ghee in a pan. Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for a minute.
Add the tomato puree and cook for 5-7 minutes.
Add the onion-cashew paste, chili powder, turmeric, and salt. Sauté for 5 minutes, stirring continuously.
Add 1 cup of water and the sugar. Bring to a simmer.
Add the paneer cubes and saffron. Simmer for 5 minutes.
Stir in the heavy cream and garam masala. Cook for 1-2 minutes on low heat. Do not boil.
Serve hot.

Ingredients: Tempering (Tadka): 2 tbsp ghee, 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1/2 tsp mustard seeds, 1/4 tsp asafoetida (hing), 1 onion (finely chopped), 1 tomato (finely chopped), 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste, 1-2 green chilies (slit), 1/2 tsp red chili powder, 1/2 tsp garam masala
Steps: Pressure cook the toor dal with turmeric, salt, and 3 cups of water for 3-4 whistles until soft.
Heat ghee in a pan for the tadka.
Add mustard seeds and cumin seeds. When they pop, add asafoetida.
Add the chopped onion, green chilies, and ginger-garlic paste. Sauté until the onion is golden.
Add the chopped tomato and cook until soft.
Add red chili powder and garam masala. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Pour this tempering over the cooked, whisked dal.
Bring the dal to a simmer and cook for 5 minutes.
Garnish with cilantro and serve.

Ingredients: 1 cup green peas (matar), fresh or frozen
Steps: Heat oil in a pressure cooker or pan.
Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add tomato puree, turmeric, coriander powder, and chili powder. Cook until oil separates.
Add the cubed potatoes and green peas. Sauté for 2-3 minutes.
Add 1.5 cups of water and salt. Mix well.
If using a pressure cooker, cook for 2 whistles. If using a pan, cover and simmer for 15-20 minutes, or until potatoes are tender.
Stir in the garam masala and garnish with cilantro.

Ingredients: Whole spices: 2 bay leaves, 1 black cardamom, 4 green cardamoms, 1-inch cinnamon, 4 cloves
Steps: Heat ghee/oil in a pressure cooker. Add the whole spices.
Add the mutton pieces and fry on high heat until browned.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 2 minutes.
Lower the heat. Add the whisked yogurt, stirring continuously.
Add chili powder, coriander, turmeric, and salt. Sauté for 5-7 minutes.
Add the cashew/almond paste and the crushed fried onions. Sauté for 3-4 minutes.
Add 1.5 cups of water. Secure the lid and pressure cook for 6-7 whistles, or until the mutton is tender.
Let the pressure release. Stir in the garam masala and serve hot.
In a large bowl, combine maida, sooji, baking soda, sugar, and salt.
Add the yogurt and 1 tbsp of oil. Mix well.
Gradually add warm water and knead into a soft, pliable dough.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest in a warm place for at least 2 hours.
Knead the dough again for a minute. Divide into equal-sized balls.
Grease the rolling surface and rolling pin with oil.
Roll each ball into an oval or round shape, not too thin.
Heat oil in a kadai over high heat.
Carefully slide the bhatura into the hot oil. Gently press it down to help it puff.
Fry until golden brown on both sides. Drain and serve immediately with chole.

Ingredients: Chettinad Masala (roast & grind): 1 tbsp coriander seeds, 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1 tsp fennel seeds, 1/2 tsp black peppercorns, 1-inch cinnamon, 4 cloves, 2 green cardamoms, 1 star anise, 4-5 dried red chilies
Steps: Dry roast all ingredients for 'Chettinad Masala' until aromatic. Let cool and grind to a fine powder.
Dry roast the grated coconut until golden brown. Grind it to a paste, adding a little water if needed.
Heat sesame oil in a pan. Add curry leaves.
Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add chopped tomato and cook until soft.
Add the ground chettinad masala, turmeric, and salt. Sauté for 2 minutes.
Add the chicken pieces and fry for 5-7 minutes.
Add the ground coconut paste and 1 cup of water (and tamarind pulp, if using).
Cover and simmer for 20-25 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through.
Serve hot with rice or parotta.

Ingredients: Marinade: 2 tbsp ginger-garlic paste, 1 tbsp red chili powder, 1/2 tsp turmeric powder, 1 tsp coriander powder, 1/2 tsp cumin powder, 1 tbsp lemon juice, Salt to taste
2 tbsp rice flour or semolina (for coating)
Steps: Wash and pat dry the fish steaks.
In a bowl, mix all the ingredients for the marinade to form a thick paste.
Coat each fish steak generously with the masala paste.
Let it marinate for at least 30 minutes in the refrigerator.
Spread the rice flour or semolina on a plate.
Dredge each marinated fish steak in the flour, coating it lightly on both sides.
Heat oil in a flat pan for shallow frying.
Carefully place the fish steaks in the hot oil.
Fry on medium heat for 4-5 minutes per side, or until golden brown, crisp, and the fish is cooked through.
Drain on a paper towel and serve hot with onion rings and lemon wedges.
Wash the mint and cilantro leaves thoroughly.
In a blender, combine all the ingredients: mint, cilantro, green chilies, ginger, lemon juice, cumin seeds, black salt, and salt.
Add 2-3 tbsp of water (or just enough to get the blender going).
Blend to a smooth paste.
Taste and adjust salt or lemon juice if needed.
Serve as a dip with samosas, pakoras, or tandoori items.
Soak the tamarind in 1 cup of hot water for 30 minutes.
Squeeze the tamarind well with your hands to extract the pulp. Strain the mixture, discarding the fibers.
Transfer the tamarind pulp to a saucepan.
Add the grated jaggery (or sugar), roasted cumin powder, ginger powder, chili powder, black salt, and regular salt.
Bring the mixture to a boil.
Simmer on low heat for 8-10 minutes, or until the chutney thickens to a sauce-like consistency.
Let it cool completely. It will thicken further as it cools.
Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

Ingredients: Vadas: 1 cup urad dal (skinned black gram), soaked 4 hours
Yogurt Mixture: 2 cups plain yogurt (dahi), whisked smooth, 1 tsp sugar, Salt
Toppings: Tamarind chutney, Mint chutney, Roasted cumin powder, Red chili powder, Chaat masala, Sev (optional)
Steps: Drain the soaked urad dal completely. Grind to a thick, fluffy paste with minimal water.
Beat the batter for 5 minutes to aerate it. Add salt.
Heat oil for deep frying. Drop spoonfuls of batter (or use the Medu Vada shaping method) into the hot oil.
Fry on medium heat until golden brown. Drain.
Have a bowl of warm water ready. Add the fried vadas to the water and let them soak for 15-20 minutes. They will soften and swell.
Gently squeeze each vada between your palms to remove excess water. Arrange them on a serving platter.
In a separate bowl, whisk the yogurt with sugar and salt until smooth.
Pour the sweet yogurt mixture generously over the vadas, covering them completely.
Chill for at least 1 hour.
Before serving, drizzle with tamarind chutney and mint chutney. Sprinkle with cumin powder, chili powder, and chaat masala.

Ingredients: Aloo Tikkis: 4 large potatoes (boiled, mashed), 2 tbsp cornflour, 1/2 tsp red chili powder, Salt

Toppings: 1/2 cup boiled chickpeas, 1/2 cup whisked yogurt, Tamarind chutney, Mint chutney, 1 onion (finely chopped), Chaat masala, Roasted cumin powder, Red chili powder, Sev (gram flour noodles), Pomegranate seeds
Steps: For tikkis: Mix mashed potatoes, cornflour, chili powder, and salt. Form into flat, round patties.
Heat oil on a flat pan (tava). Shallow fry the tikkis on medium heat until golden brown and crisp on both sides.
To assemble: Place 2 hot aloo tikkis on a plate.
Crush them slightly. Top with a spoonful of boiled chickpeas.
Drizzle generously with whisked yogurt, tamarind chutney, and mint chutney.
Sprinkle with chopped onions, chaat masala, cumin powder, and red chili powder.
Garnish with sev and pomegranate seeds. Serve immediately.

Ingredients: Pani (Spicy Water): 1 cup mint leaves, 1/2 cup cilantro, 1-2 green chilies, 1-inch ginger, 1 small ball of tamarind, 1 tbsp pani puri masala, 1/2 tsp black salt, 4 cups cold water
Filling: 1 cup boiled chickpeas, 1 cup boiled potato (cubed), 1/4 cup chopped onion (optional)
Steps: For pani: Blend mint, cilantro, chilies, ginger, and tamarind with a little water to a smooth paste.
Strain this paste into a large bowl. Add 4 cups of cold water.
Stir in the pani puri masala, black salt, and regular salt. Taste and adjust. Chill the pani.
For filling: In a bowl, lightly mash the boiled potatoes and chickpeas. Add chopped onion if using. Add a pinch of salt and chaat masala.
To serve: Crack a small hole in the top of one puri.
Stuff it with a small amount of the potato-chickpea filling.
Dip the stuffed puri into the chilled pani, fill it up, and eat it whole immediately.

Ingredients: 1/4 cup raw mango, finely chopped (if in season)
Steps: In a large bowl, combine the puffed rice, peanuts, sev, and crushed papdis. (Add these dry ingredients just before serving to keep them crisp).
Add the chopped onion, tomato, boiled potato, and raw mango.
Pour the tamarind chutney and mint chutney over the mixture.
Sprinkle with chaat masala and chopped cilantro.
Add the lemon juice.
Toss everything together quickly and lightly until well combined.
Serve immediately, garnished with more sev and cilantro.

Ingredients: Kadhi: 1 cup sour yogurt, 1/2 cup gram flour (besan), 1/2 tsp turmeric powder, 1/2 tsp red chili powder, 6 cups water, Salt
Pakoras: 1 cup besan, 1 onion (chopped), 1/2 tsp ajwain, 1/4 tsp baking soda, Salt, Water, Oil for frying
Tempering: 2 tbsp ghee, 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1/4 tsp asafoetida (hing), 1 sprig curry leaves, 2-3 dried red chilies
Steps: For pakoras: Mix all pakora ingredients (except oil) to make a thick batter. Deep fry small spoonfuls until golden. Keep aside.
For kadhi: In a large pot, whisk yogurt, 1/2 cup besan, turmeric, chili powder, and salt. Whisk until no lumps remain.
Slowly add 6 cups of water, whisking continuously.
Place the pot on medium heat. Bring to a boil, stirring constantly to prevent curdling.
Once it boils, reduce heat and let it simmer for 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the kadhi thickens.
Add the fried pakoras to the simmering kadhi. Cook for 5 more minutes.
For tempering: Heat ghee. Add all tempering ingredients. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Pour the hot tempering over the kadhi. Serve hot with rice.

Ingredients: Tempering (Tadka): 2 tbsp ghee, 1 large onion (finely chopped), 1 tbsp ginger-garlic paste, 1/2 tsp red chili powder, 1/4 tsp asafoetida
Steps: Wash and chop all the greens.
In a pressure cooker, add the greens, chopped ginger, green chilies, salt, and 1/2 cup of water.
Pressure cook for 4-5 whistles until the greens are very soft.
Let the pressure release. Open the lid and add the maize flour. Blend the greens using an immersion blender (or mash well) to a coarse, thick puree.
Simmer the saag for 10-15 minutes on low heat, stirring.
For tadka: Heat ghee in a separate pan. Add asafoetida.
Add the chopped onion and sauté until deep golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and red chili powder. Sauté for 1 minute.
Pour this tadka over the cooked saag. Mix well.
Serve hot with a dollop of white butter and Makki ki Roti.

Ingredients: Hot water, as needed to knead
Steps: In a bowl, combine the maize flour, ajwain, and salt.
Gradually add hot water (as hot as you can handle) and start kneading the dough.
Knead for 5-7 minutes. The dough should be soft and smooth. (This dough is gluten-free, so it needs good kneading).
Take a small portion of the dough. Knead it again for 30 seconds.
Place the dough ball on a piece of parchment paper or a plastic sheet. Wet your palms.
Pat the dough with your palms to flatten it into a round circle (roti). It's difficult to roll with a pin.
Heat a tava (griddle) over medium heat.
Carefully lift the parchment paper and flip the roti onto the hot tava.
Cook for about 1 minute, then flip. Cook the other side for 1-2 minutes.
Finally, cook it directly on the open flame (optional, for a smoky flavor) or cook on the tava, pressing with a cloth, until brown spots appear.
Generously brush with ghee and serve immediately with Sarson Ka Saag.

Ingredients: 1 large capsicum (bell pepper), cut into 1.5-inch squares

Marinade: 1 cup thick yogurt, 2 tbsp gram flour (besan), 1 tbsp ginger-garlic paste, 1 tsp Kashmiri red chili powder, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1 tsp garam masala, 1 tsp chaat masala, 1 tbsp lemon juice, 1 tbsp mustard oil, Salt
Steps: In a bowl, whisk all the ingredients for the marinade until smooth. (Lightly roast the besan for a better taste).
Add the paneer cubes, onion squares, and capsicum squares to the marinade.
Gently toss to coat everything evenly. Cover and refrigerate for at least 1 hour.
Thread the marinated paneer, onion, and capsicum pieces onto wooden skewers (soak skewers in water first).
Heat a non-stick tawa (griddle) or pan with 1 tbsp of oil.
Place the skewers on the hot tawa. Cook on medium heat.
Keep turning the skewers every 2-3 minutes, basting with a little oil, until all sides are golden brown and charred.
Sprinkle with chaat masala and serve hot with mint chutney.

Ingredients: Whole spices: 1 black cardamom, 2 green cardamoms, 1-inch cinnamon, 2 cloves
Steps: Prick the boiled baby potatoes all over with a fork.
Heat mustard oil in a pan. Deep fry the potatoes on medium heat until they are golden brown and crisp on the outside. Drain and set aside.
In a separate pan, heat 2 tbsp of ghee. Add asafoetida and the whole spices.
Lower the heat. Add the Kashmiri red chili powder, followed quickly by the whisked yogurt, stirring constantly to prevent curdling.
Add fennel powder, ginger powder, and salt. Cook the masala for 3-4 minutes.
Add the fried potatoes and 1.5 cups of water. Bring to a boil.
Cover and simmer on low heat for 15-20 minutes, allowing the potatoes to absorb the gravy.
The gravy will thicken and become a deep red. Stir in garam masala. Serve hot.

Ingredients: 1 cup yellow moong dal (skinned yellow lentils), soaked for 4 hours
Steps: Drain the soaked moong dal. Grind it to a coarse paste (without adding water).
In a heavy-bottomed pan, heat the ghee.
Add the ground moong dal paste to the hot ghee.
Stir continuously on low-medium heat. This is the most important step. The dal will first be sticky, then lumpy, and finally will break down into a granular, sand-like texture.
Roast for 30-45 minutes, or until the dal paste is golden brown and aromatic, and the ghee separates.
While the dal is roasting, combine sugar, milk, and water in a separate saucepan. Bring to a boil.
Once the dal is roasted, slowly and carefully pour the hot milk-sugar-water mixture into the pan. It will splutter.
Stir vigorously to prevent lumps. The mixture will absorb the liquid quickly.
Continue to cook on low heat, stirring, until the halwa thickens and starts to leave the sides of the pan (about 10-15 minutes).
Stir in the cardamom powder and nuts. Serve hot.

Ingredients: Rabri (Milk): 1 liter full-fat milk, 1/2 cup sugar, 1/2 tsp cardamom powder, 2 tbsp chopped pistachios & almonds, Saffron strands
Steps: Make 'chena' (curdled milk solids) from 1 liter of milk and lemon juice, as in the Rasgulla recipe. Squeeze and knead until smooth.
Make small, flat discs from the chena.
Boil sugar and water in a wide pot. Add the chena discs. Cover and boil for 15-20 minutes. The discs will double in size.
Let them cool. Gently squeeze out the syrup.
For rabri: In a heavy pan, boil the other 1 liter of milk. Simmer on low heat, stirring often, until it reduces to about half its quantity.
Add sugar, cardamom powder, saffron, and nuts to the reduced milk. Stir until sugar dissolves. Let the rabri cool completely.
Add the cooled, squeezed chena discs (rasgullas) to the cooled rabri.
Chill in the refrigerator for at least 4-6 hours, allowing the discs to soak up the rabri.
Serve chilled, garnished with more nuts.

Ingredients: 1 large onion, finely chopped and squeezed of all water
Steps: In a bowl, combine the chicken mince with all other ingredients (squeezed onion, cilantro, chilies, ginger-garlic, spices, besan, lemon juice, butter, salt).
Mix very well, kneading the mixture for 5 minutes.
Refrigerate the mixture for at least 1 hour.
Grease your palms. Take a portion of the mixture and press it around a metal skewer, shaping it into a long, cylindrical kebab (seekh).
Preheat your oven's grill/broiler to high.
Place the skewers on a grill rack with a tray underneath.
Grill for 10-12 minutes, turning halfway through, until cooked and lightly charred.
Alternatively, pan-fry on a tawa, turning, until cooked through.
Carefully remove from skewers. Serve hot with mint chutney and onion rings.

Ingredients: 1 large onion, finely chopped and squeezed
Steps: Combine mutton mince, squeezed onion, ginger-garlic, chilies, cilantro, papaya paste, all spices, besan, ghee, and salt.
Knead the mixture for 5-10 minutes until it becomes sticky and holds together.
Refrigerate for at least 2 hours.
Grease your palms. Take a portion of the mixture and press it around a metal skewer, shaping it into a long kebab.
Grill in a preheated oven or on a tawa (as in Chicken Seekh Kebab recipe) until cooked through and charred.
Baste with ghee or butter while grilling.
Serve hot with mint chutney.

Ingredients: Masala Paste (roast & grind): 1/4 cup peanuts, 2 tbsp sesame seeds, 2 tbsp grated dry coconut, 1 tsp coriander seeds, 1 tsp cumin seeds
Steps: Dry roast peanuts, sesame seeds, coconut, coriander, and cumin seeds separately. Let cool and grind to a smooth paste with a little water.
Wash the brinjals. Make two perpendicular slits from the bottom, keeping the stems intact.
Heat oil in a pan. Fry the brinjals until the skin shrivels and they are 80% cooked. Remove and set aside.
In the same oil, add mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, and curry leaves.
Add the sliced onion and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add the ground masala paste, turmeric, and chili powder. Sauté for 5-7 minutes, until the oil separates.
Add the tamarind pulp, jaggery (if using), salt, and 1.5 cups of water. Bring to a boil.
Gently add the fried brinjals to the gravy.
Cover and simmer on low heat for 10-15 minutes, until the brinjals are fully cooked and gravy has thickened.
Serve hot with biryani or roti.

Ingredients: Tempering: 2 tbsp oil, 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 sprig curry leaves, 3-4 green chilies (slit), 1/2 cup water, 2 tbsp sugar, 1/4 tsp asafoetida
Steps: In a bowl, mix besan, citric acid, sugar, ginger-chili paste, and salt. Add 3/4 cup water to make a smooth, lump-free batter.
Grease a steaming pan. Boil water in a steamer.
Just before steaming, add the Eno fruit salt to the batter and 1 tsp of water on top of it. Stir quickly and vigorously for 10-15 seconds. The batter will become very frothy.
Pour immediately into the greased pan.
Steam on high heat for 12-15 minutes. Check with a toothpick; it should come out clean.
Let the khaman cool for 10 minutes, then invert onto a plate and cut into squares.
For tempering: Heat oil. Add mustard seeds, asafoetida, curry leaves, and green chilies. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add 1/2 cup water and 2 tbsp sugar. Bring to a boil.
Pour this hot tempering evenly over the khaman pieces.
Garnish with cilantro and grated coconut. Serve.

Ingredients: 1.5 cups Basmati rice, soaked for 30 minutes
2 cups mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, beans, potatoes, cauliflower)
Whole spices: 1 bay leaf, 2-inch cinnamon, 4 green cardamoms, 4 cloves, 1 star anise
Steps: Heat ghee/oil in a pot or pressure cooker.
Add the cumin seeds and all the whole spices. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add the sliced onion and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add all the mixed vegetables. Sauté on high heat for 3-4 minutes.
Add the soaked and drained rice. Sauté gently for 1-2 minutes.
Add the water (or broth), salt, and garam masala. Bring to a boil.
If in a pot, cover tightly, reduce heat to low, and simmer for 15-18 minutes. If in a pressure cooker, cook for 2 whistles.
Let it rest for 10 minutes before opening. Fluff with a fork and serve with raita.
Make small slits in the hard-boiled eggs. (Optional: lightly fry them in 1 tsp of oil until golden spots appear).
Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds.
Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add the tomato puree, turmeric, coriander powder, chili powder, and salt.
Cook the masala on medium-low heat until it thickens and oil separates.
Add 1.5 cups of water to the pan. Bring the gravy to a boil.
Gently slide the hard-boiled eggs into the gravy.
Cover and simmer for 8-10 minutes.
Stir in the garam masala. Garnish with cilantro and serve hot.

Ingredients: 500g firm white fish, cut into pieces
Whole spices: 2 bay leaves, 4 green cardamoms, 1-inch cinnamon, 4 cloves
Steps: Crush the fried onions. Set aside.
Heat ghee/oil in a pan. Add the whole spices.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for 1 minute.
Lower the heat. Add whisked yogurt, chili powder, and turmeric. Stir quickly.
Add the cashew paste and crushed fried onions. Sauté for 3-4 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add 1.5 cups of water and salt. Bring the gravy to a gentle simmer.
Gently add the fish pieces to the simmering gravy.
Cover and cook on low heat for 8-10 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through. Do not over-stir.
Sprinkle with garam masala and serve.
Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds.
Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add tomato puree, turmeric, coriander, and chili powder. Cook until oil separates.
Add the cashew paste and cook for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add the quartered mushrooms and salt. Sauté for 5-7 minutes, until mushrooms release water and are cooked.
Add 1/2 cup of water (or as needed for gravy). Bring to a simmer.
Cover and cook for 5 minutes.
Stir in the garam masala and serve hot.

Ingredients: 1.5 cups Basmati rice, soaked for 30 minutes
Steps: Drain the soaked rice.
Heat ghee in a pot or pressure cooker.
Add the cumin seeds, bay leaf, cinnamon, and cardamoms. Sauté until the cumin seeds splutter and are aromatic.
Add the drained rice. Sauté gently for 2 minutes, being careful not to break the grains.
Add 3 cups of water and salt. Bring to a boil.
If in a pot, cover tightly, reduce heat to low, and simmer for 15 minutes. If in a pressure cooker, cook for 2 whistles.
Let it rest for 10 minutes before opening. Fluff with a fork.
Garnish with cilantro and serve with dal or curry.

Ingredients: 500g rohu or katla fish, cut into steaks
Steps: Rub the fish steaks with 1/2 tsp turmeric and salt. Rub the potatoes with 1/4 tsp turmeric and salt.
Heat mustard oil in a pan until it's smoking hot. Lower the heat.
Fry the fish steaks in batches until golden brown. Remove and set aside.
In the same oil, fry the potatoes until golden brown. Remove and set aside.
In the remaining oil, add the panch phoron and bay leaf. Let them splutter.
Add the sliced onion and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add chopped tomato, coriander powder, chili powder, remaining turmeric, and salt. Cook until tomatoes are mushy.
Add 2 cups of hot water and bring to a boil.
Add the fried potatoes and cook for 5-7 minutes.
Gently add the fried fish pieces. Simmer for 5-7 minutes, until the fish absorbs the gravy.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

Ingredients: Misal (Curry): 2 cups sprouted moth beans (matki), boiled
Curry Paste: 1/2 cup grated dry coconut, 1 onion (sliced), 1-inch ginger, 4-5 cloves garlic, 1 tbsp coriander seeds (all roasted and ground)
2 tbsp Goda masala or Misal masala
Toppings: Farsan (mixed fried snacks), 1 large onion (finely chopped), 1/4 cup chopped cilantro, Lemon wedges
Steps: Heat 3 tbsp oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Add the ground curry paste and sauté until oil separates.
Add the Goda masala, red chili powder, turmeric, and salt. Sauté for 1-2 minutes.
Add the boiled sprouts and 3-4 cups of water. Bring to a rolling boil.
Simmer for 10-15 minutes. The curry (rass) should be thin and spicy.
To serve: In a bowl, add a portion of the sprouted bean curry.
Top generously with farsan, chopped onion, and cilantro.
Drizzle with lemon juice. Serve hot with pav.

Ingredients: 1 tbsp tamarind pulp (or 1 tsp lemon juice)
Steps: Marinate the prawns with 1/4 tsp turmeric and salt for 15 minutes.
Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds and curry leaves.
Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add the tomato puree, remaining turmeric, chili powder, and coriander powder.
Cook the masala until oil separates.
Add the marinated prawns. Sauté on high heat for 2-3 minutes, until they turn pink.
Lower the heat. Add the coconut milk, tamarind pulp, and salt.
Stir gently and bring to a gentle simmer. Do not boil vigorously.
Cook for 3-5 minutes, or until the prawns are just cooked through. (Do not overcook prawns).
Serve hot with rice.

Ingredients: Koftas: 2 cups grated bottle gourd (lauki), 1/2 cup gram flour (besan), 1/2 tsp red chili powder, 1/4 tsp turmeric, Salt, Oil for frying

Gravy: 1 large onion (chopped), 2 tomatoes (pureed), 1 tbsp ginger-garlic paste, 1/4 cup cashew paste, 1/2 tsp cumin seeds, 1 tsp coriander powder, 1/2 tsp red chili powder, 1/4 tsp turmeric, 1/2 tsp garam masala, 2 tbsp oil, Salt
Steps: For koftas: Squeeze out all the water from the grated lauki. Reserve the water.
In a bowl, mix the squeezed lauki, besan, chili powder, turmeric, and salt. Do not add water. Form a tight dough.
Make small balls and deep fry on medium heat until golden brown. Keep aside.
For gravy: Heat 2 tbsp oil. Add cumin seeds.
Add chopped onion and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste. Sauté for 1 minute.
Add tomato puree and all the spice powders (except garam masala). Cook until oil separates.
Add the cashew paste and sauté for 2 minutes.
Add 1.5 cups of water (use the reserved lauki water first). Bring to a boil.
Add salt and simmer the gravy for 5-7 minutes.
Just before serving, add the fried koftas and garam masala. Simmer for 2 minutes and serve hot.
Crack the eggs into a bowl, add salt, and whisk lightly. Set aside.
Heat oil in a pan. Add the chopped onion, green chilies, and ginger.
Sauté on medium heat until the onion is soft and translucent.
Add the chopped tomatoes and turmeric. Cook until the tomatoes are soft and mushy.
Add the red chili powder and garam masala (if using). Stir for 30 seconds.
Pour in the whisked eggs.
Let the eggs set for 30 seconds, then start scrambling them with a spatula.
Continue to cook, stirring, for 2-3 minutes, until the eggs are cooked to your liking.
Turn off the heat and stir in the chopped cilantro.
Serve hot with pav, roti, or bread.
Heat the ghee in a heavy-bottomed pan (kadai) on low heat.
Add the besan to the melted ghee.
Roast the besan on a strictly low heat, stirring continuously.
This process will take 30-40 minutes. The besan will first become lumpy, then loosen up, and finally turn a deep golden brown, releasing a nutty aroma and ghee.
Once roasted, turn off the heat. Stir in the cardamom powder and nuts.
Let the mixture cool down. It should be just warm to the touch (not hot, or the sugar will melt).
Add the powdered sugar to the warm besan-ghee mixture.
Mix well with your hands until the sugar is fully incorporated.
Take small portions of the mixture and shape them into round balls (ladoos).
Let the ladoos set at room temperature for a few hours. Store in an airtight container.
Grind the cashews in a dry blender to a fine powder. Sift it to ensure there are no lumps.
In a non-stick pan, combine the sugar and water. Heat on medium flame until the sugar dissolves completely.
Bring the syrup to a boil and cook until it reaches a 'one-string consistency'.
Reduce the heat to low. Add the cashew powder, cardamom powder, and rose water.
Stir continuously. The mixture will thicken quickly.
Keep stirring for 5-7 minutes until the mixture comes together as a single, non-sticky dough, leaving the sides of the pan.
Add the 1 tsp of ghee and mix well.
Transfer the dough to a greased sheet of parchment paper.
Let it cool for 1-2 minutes. While it's still warm, knead the dough for 1 minute until smooth.
Place another sheet of parchment paper on top and roll the dough to 1/4 inch thickness.
Let it cool and set for 1-2 hours (or 15-20 mins in the fridge).
Cut into diamond shapes. (Optional: decorate with edible silver vark).
Dry roast the rava in a pan on low heat for 5-7 minutes until aromatic. Do not let it change color. Remove and keep aside.
Heat ghee/oil in the same pan. Add mustard seeds, urad dal, and chana dal. Sauté until golden.
Add ginger, green chilies, and curry leaves. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add the chopped onion and sauté until translucent.
Add the optional vegetables and cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add 2.5 cups of hot water and salt. Bring to a rolling boil.
Reduce the heat to low. Slowly pour in the roasted rava, stirring continuously with the other hand to prevent lumps.
Keep stirring until the rava absorbs all the water and thickens.
Cover the pan and cook on the lowest heat for 3-5 minutes.
Turn off the heat. Add the lemon juice and 1 tsp of ghee. Fluff with a fork and serve hot.

Ingredients: Masala (Spices): 1-inch ginger (crushed), 2 green cardamoms (crushed), 1-inch cinnamon stick, 2 cloves
Steps: In a saucepan, add the 1 cup of water, crushed ginger, cardamom, cinnamon, and cloves.
Bring the water to a rolling boil. Let it boil for 1-2 minutes for the spices to infuse.
Add the 2 tsp of tea leaves. Let it boil for another minute.
Add the 1 cup of milk and the sugar.
Bring the mixture back to a boil. Be careful, as it can boil over quickly.
Reduce the heat and let the chai simmer for 2-3 minutes to get a strong flavor and color.
Strain the chai through a tea strainer into cups.
Serve hot.

Ingredients: 1/2 tsp pav bhaji masala (or garam masala)
Steps: Heat oil/butter in a pan. Add the cumin seeds.
Add the chopped onion, green chilies, and capsicum. Sauté until the onion is soft.
Add the chopped tomatoes, turmeric, red chili powder, and salt.
Cook until the tomatoes are soft and mushy.
Add the crumbled paneer to the pan.
Stir and cook for 3-4 minutes, mixing the paneer well with the masala.
Sprinkle the pav bhaji masala (or garam masala) and mix.
Turn off the heat and stir in the chopped cilantro.
Serve hot with roti, pav, or as a sandwich filling.

Ingredients: Tempering: 2 tbsp ghee, 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1/4 tsp asafoetida (hing), 1 onion (chopped), 2-3 cloves garlic (chopped), 1-2 dried red chilies, 1/2 tsp red chili powder
Steps: Wash and rinse the toor dal. In a pressure cooker, add the dal, chopped spinach, turmeric, salt, and 3 cups of water.
Pressure cook for 3-4 whistles until the dal is completely soft.
Whisk the dal lightly.
For tempering: Heat ghee in a small pan.
Add cumin seeds and asafoetida. When they splutter, add the dried red chilies and chopped garlic.
Sauté until the garlic is golden.
Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown.
Turn off the heat. Add the red chili powder and immediately pour the tempering over the cooked dal.
Mix well and simmer for 2 minutes. Serve hot with rice.

Ingredients: 1 cup sago (sabudana), rinsed and soaked for 4-6 hours
1/2 cup raw peanuts, roasted, peeled, and coarsely crushed
1 sprig curry leaves (optional, not for fasting)
Salt to taste (sendha namak for fasting)
Steps: Drain the soaked sabudana completely. It should be soft but not mushy.
In a bowl, gently mix the drained sabudana, crushed peanuts, salt, and sugar.
Heat ghee/oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add the green chilies and curry leaves. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add the boiled potato cubes and sauté for 1-2 minutes.
Add the sabudana-peanut mixture to the pan.
Stir gently and cook on low-medium heat for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the sabudana turns translucent.
Turn off the heat. Add the lemon juice and mix well.
Garnish with chopped cilantro and serve hot.

Ingredients: Whole spices: 1 bay leaf, 1-inch cinnamon, 2 cloves, 2 cardamoms
Steps: Heat oil in a pressure cooker or pot.
Add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, curry leaves, and all the whole spices. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add the sliced onion and sauté until translucent.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add the tomato puree, turmeric, chili powder, and salt. Cook for 5-7 minutes, until the oil separates.
Add the soaked and drained rice. Sauté gently for 1-2 minutes.
Add 2.5 cups of water. Stir well and bring to a boil.
If in a pot, cover and simmer on low heat for 15-18 minutes. If in a pressure cooker, cook for 2 whistles.
Let it rest for 10 minutes. Stir in the garam masala and fluff with a fork.
Serve hot with raita or papad.

Ingredients: A generous pinch of saffron strands (soaked in 1 tbsp warm milk)
Steps: Heat 1 tbsp of ghee in a pan. Fry the cashews until golden, then add raisins and fry until they plump up. Remove and set aside.
In the same pan, add the remaining ghee. Add the rava and roast on low heat for 7-10 minutes, until it's aromatic and lightly golden. Remove and set aside.
In the same pan, add 2 cups of water and the saffron milk. Bring to a rolling boil.
Reduce the heat to low. Slowly pour in the roasted rava, stirring continuously to prevent lumps.
Keep stirring until the rava absorbs all the water and is cooked.
Add the sugar. The mixture will become liquidy again. Keep stirring.
Continue to cook, stirring, until the mixture thickens and starts to leave the sides of the pan.
Add the cardamom powder, fried cashews, and raisins. Mix well.
Serve hot or at room temperature.

Ingredients: 2 large carrots, finely chopped or grated
Tempering: 1 tbsp coconut oil, 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 tsp urad dal, 1 dried red chili (broken), 1 sprig curry leaves, 1/4 tsp asafoetida (hing)
Steps: Heat coconut oil in a pan. Add all the tempering ingredients.
Sauté until the mustard seeds pop and the urad dal turns golden brown.
Add the finely chopped carrots and salt.
Sprinkle 2-3 tbsp of water. Cover the pan and cook on low heat for 5-7 minutes, or until the carrots are tender.
Remove the lid, add the grated fresh coconut.
Stir and cook for 1-2 minutes until the coconut is heated through.
Serve hot as a side dish with rice and sambar/rasam.

Ingredients: 2 medium beetroots, peeled and finely chopped
Tempering: 1 tbsp coconut oil, 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 tsp urad dal, 1 dried red chili, 1 sprig curry leaves
Steps: Heat coconut oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds, urad dal, red chili, and curry leaves.
Sauté until the dal turns golden.
Add the finely chopped beetroot and salt.
Sprinkle 1/4 cup of water. Cover and cook on low heat for 10-12 minutes, or until the beetroot is tender.
Remove the lid and cook for 2-3 minutes if there is any excess water.
Add the grated fresh coconut. Stir and cook for 1-2 minutes.
Serve hot as a side dish.

Ingredients: Tempering: 1 tbsp coconut oil, 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 tsp urad dal, 1 tsp chana dal, 2 green chilies (slit), 1 sprig curry leaves
Steps: Heat coconut oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds, urad dal, and chana dal. Sauté until golden.
Add the green chilies and curry leaves.
Add the shredded cabbage, turmeric, and salt.
Stir-fry on medium-high heat for 3-4 minutes. Do not add water.
Cover and cook on low heat for 5-7 minutes. The cabbage should be tender yet crunchy, not mushy.
Remove the lid, add the grated fresh coconut.
Stir and cook for 1-2 minutes. Serve hot.

Ingredients: 1 tbsp tamarind pulp, soaked in 1 cup warm water
1 tbsp toor dal, cooked and mashed (optional)
Tempering: 1 tsp ghee, 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1/4 tsp asafoetida, 2 dried red chilies, 1 sprig curry leaves
Steps: In a pot, combine the mashed tomato, tamarind water, cooked toor dal (if using), rasam powder, turmeric, salt, and 2 cups of water.
Bring the mixture to a boil.
Let it simmer on low heat for 10-15 minutes, until it becomes frothy on top. Do not over-boil.
For tempering: Heat ghee in a small pan. Add all tempering ingredients.
Sauté until the seeds pop and curry leaves are crisp.
Pour the hot tempering over the rasam.
Stir in the chopped cilantro and turn off the heat.
Cover and let it rest for 5 minutes for the flavors to blend.
Serve hot as a soup or with rice.
